awd_titl_txt: A Multiscale View of the Effects of Stellar Feedback in the Local Universe
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). Rebecca Levy is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to conduct a program of research and education at the University of Arizona.  Levy will undertake radio and optical observations of nearby galaxies to understand the distribution of ionized regions and molecular gas within star-forming regions at scales ranging from individual protostars to galactic winds.  Results from this study will allow astronomers to understand how processes controlling star formation influence the spatial and temporal evolution of galaxies.  For the education component of her project, Levy will conduct a weekly program to develop the scientific identities and confidence of tribal middle school students.

This project will elucidate how the processes of star formation and stellar feedback shape galaxies in the local Universe. Measurements of the sizes and structures of HII regions around massive young forming clusters in NGC 253, in concert with a previous molecular gas analysis, will probe the impact of the clusters on shaping their environment and powering the nuclear starburst. In M82, the observations will trace the bulk of the neutral material and reveal the cooling and fate of the wind, answering fundamental questions about the state of the largest mass reservoir in the wind.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

The outcomes of this award, carried out by PI Dr. Rebecca Levy at the University of Arizona from 10/01/2021 - 09/22/2024, are described below.

Intellectual Merit

The scientific results of this award are documented in 4 first-author publications in peer-reviewed journals (summarized below). Additionally, the I was a co-author on 17 publications in peer-reviewed journals during the fellowship tenure. Results were disseminated via 23 oral presentations at conferences and seminars.

Background:
The gas and dust between stars in a galaxy is called the interstellar medium (ISM). Starburst galaxies form stars at an elevated rate. In these extreme systems, stars form in dense, compact groups called "super star clusters" (SSCs). The number and concentration of stars in SSCs inject huge amounts of energy and momentum (i.e., "feedback") into their surrounding ISM. This concerted feedback can cause material to be evacuated from the galaxy, as a biconical "outflow" or "wind."

  • "The Morpho-Kinematic Architecture of Super Star Clusters in the Center of NGC 253" (Levy et al. 2022, Astrophys. J.) reports two significant results on the prototypical starburst galaxy NGC253 using data from the NSF-funded Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) telescope. We detect emission from cold dust grains in the outflow from NGC253 for the first time with ALMA. Second, we show that the SSCs in the galaxy center are arranged in a 3D ring, similar to what is seen in other galaxies and our own Milky Way. Not only did this result change our understanding of NGC253 (e.g., https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sculptor_Galaxy#Starburst ref [15]), it demonstrated that the primary theory for the formation of starbursts is largely correct.
  • "[CII] Spectral Mapping of the Galactic Wind and Starbursting Disk of M82 with SOFIA" (Levy et al. 2023, Astrophys. J.) presents new results from the Stratospheric Observatory for Infrared Astronomy (SOFIA) on the archetypal starburst galaxy M82. We report a definitive detection of the [CII] spectral line at a wavelength of 158 microns in the outflow from this galaxy. This [CII] line governs the heating and cooling of the ISM, and is critical to measure and understand. M82 is often used as a template for high-redshift galaxies in which the [CII] line is often observed. Our results show that most of the [CII] emission arises from cold material in the outflow, in agreement with predictions but which had never been tested in an outflow environment.
  • "JWST Observations of Starbursts: Massive Star Clusters in the Central Starburst of M82" (Levy et al. 2024, Astrophys. J. Letters) presents results using new data from the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) in the center of M82. We report the detection of 1357 massive SSCs in the center of M82, an order of magnitude more than had been discovered with the Hubble Space Telescope. These SSCs have stellar masses >10,000 solar masses (which is roughly the mass of the biggest star cluster in the Milky Way).
    • Another result published as part of this collaboration (Bolatto, Levy, et al. 2024, Astrophys. J.) was the subject of a NASA Press Release in which I am quoted: https://science.nasa.gov/missions/webb/nasas-webb-probes-an-extreme-starburst-galaxy/
  • "Milky Way and Nearby Galaxies Science with the SALTUS Space Observatory" (Levy et al. 2024, J. Astron. Teles., Inst., Sys.) presents the Milky Way and nearby galaxies science case for the Single Aperture Large Telescope for Universe Studies (SALTUS) far-infrared space mission concept. Although SALTUS was not selected to move forward, this paper serves as a record of this mission's goals and a launching point for future far-infrared space telescope concepts.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts goals of this award are to engage with students from traditionally underserved communities and who are underrepresented in STEM fields to increase their scientific identity and to see the applicability of STEM in their everyday lives. I accomplished this by engaging in two programs led by the Women in Science and Engineering (WISE) program at U. Arizona.

  • "Imagine Your STEM Future" (IYSF) brings hands-on STEM activities to girls at Desert View High School in Tucson, AZ, which has a minority enrollment of 96%. The main contribution to this program from this award is curriculum to teach the phases of the moon in an interactive, hands-on manner. This lesson was developed, piloted, and implented into the IYSF curriculum and is freely available online for broader use: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1UUYzn8Jej_imQFitYFOTIEtYxPLFBB2p?usp=drive_link. I was also a guest speaker for IYSF twice, presenting my career path, and funds from this award were used to repurchase consumable materials for IYSF lessons.
  • The "Bio/Diversity Project" aims to teach K-12 students in Tucson, AZ about the local ecology in a hands-on, place-based, culturally-relevant manner and to get students excited about environmental science. This program is led by undergraduates from the U. Arizona who complete the "Internship Program," a for-credit course. I delivered a guest lecture during the course on "Translational Science Communication" which is now formally included in the curriculum.
